attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset shows the boundaries, areas and identifiers (eg KY7 6DG) of the postcodes covering the whole of Scotland.
The postcode polygons are created by a team of digitisers within NRS Geography Branch.
The dataset is revised regularly, using address and postcode information provided by Royal Mail (via a third party provider). The digitisers also make use of maps and address information supplied by Scotlands local authorities. The digitisers use Ordnance Survey MasterMap as the background map to determine the boundaries of each of each postcode polygon.
NRS produce 2 versions of the boundaries, one containing Royal Mail Delivery Point information and another excluding this data.

gmd:country.gmd:Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & N. Ireland

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: The following attribution statement must be used to acknowledge the source of the information: Contains NRS data Crown copyright and database right (insert year), contains Ordnance Survey data Crown copyright and database right (insert year).

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Available under the Ordnance Survey (OS) Open Data Licence (www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/opendata/licence)
Postcode Extract data is freely available to One Scotland Mapping Agreement (OSMA) members. Other organisations should contact geographycustomerservices@nrscotland.gov.uk

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset shows the boundaries, areas and identifiers (eg KY7 6DG) of the postcodes covering the whole of Scotland.
Geography Branch first began plotting postcode boundaries in 1973. The Post Office (as it was at that time) assigned addresses to postcodes and Geography Branch staff manually traced the boundaries around the addresses using Ordnance Survey 1:2 500 maps in urban areas and 1:10,000 and 1:50,000 maps in rural areas to reference the boundary lines.
The postcode boundary dataset represents the smallest plotted administrative unit in Scotland. As a result it is possible to assign any Scottish postcode to any entity (area) within a Scottish boundary dataset. In 1973 the process of assigning postcodes to these higher geographies was entirely manual (for example, using romers to establish National Grid coordinates) and the individual postcodes were assigned to approximately 15 types of area eg council areas, health boards, electoral wards. The ability to assign postcodes to these higher geographies represented a significant step in being able to create and interpret statistics about particular locations and areas.
Since 1981 these plotted postcodes have been used as the basis for planning the workload of the Census enumerators by grouping together a number of postcodes which contain information on the number of households, it is possible to create areas (Census Enumeration Districts) which have a similar workload.
In the late 1980s Geography Branch replaced the manual tracing methods with the introduction of the Geographic Information System, GenaMap. In addition to providing the ability to produce digital boundaries, the system also automated the process of assigning postcodes to the higher geographies. The GenaMap system used the OS 1:10,000 raster maps as the background for the digitising of the postcode boundaries.
In the 2006 GenaMap was replaced by ESRIs ArcGIS product. Since the introduction of ArcGIS, Geography Branch utilises Ordnance Surveys (very accurate and detailed) MasterMap as the base map for positioning the postcode boundaries it has also embarked on a programme of improving the alignments of some of the boundaries that were first created by manual methods.
Every year-quarter Royal Mail provides to Geography Branch details of new and deleted postcodes. This information is augmented by information from local authorities. Using all available data, the Geography Branch digitisers plot the changes to the dataset. Also, every year-quarter OS provides to Geography Branch details of its product AddressPoint. Geography Branch uses this product to check the postcodes, amending any as required.
NRS produce 2 versions of the boundaries, one containing Royal Mail Delivery Point information and another excluding this data.
This dataset is continuously revised and it is formally issued twice a year as part of the Scottish Postcode Directory. In addition to the postcode boundaries, the Scottish Postcode Directory contains a database/index detailing the higher geographies which each postcode is assigned to.

gmd:country.gmd:Country: United Kingdom of Great Britain & N. Ireland
